number of helpful: 385 of 417 people (92%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												When I say that I'd reccomend this game it's only to a small niche of people. Because I happen to fall in the niche I rather liked Universe Sandbox, though I can see where many people woud not. Universe Sandbox is pretty self explanatory in the title, its a astrophysics sandbox in which you can create and destroy solar systems, galaxys, or even galaxy clusters (if your computer is beefy enough) Many stats and attributes are tracked as you simulate the astral dance of heavenly bodies.         Things like density, spin, velocity, mass, and heat are all tracked and simulated to give you the most realistic expierience possible. Unfortunately, it doesnt get very realistic. My biggest gripe I would suppose is the physics. The game uses Eular math, or if you have a processing power Runge Kata. But eventually stable orbits will do someting completely random, sending a few planets and stars on random vectors straight out if your little "pitri dish". This doesnt bother me too much because it mostly only happens when it comes to simulating galaxies. On the solar system level it does quite well and it has enough options to accomodate nearly any computer's processing power. That is, if you can navigate the menus.           Theres lots of options and statistics for every celestial body and you can edit every fascet. the problem is, this creates a very confusing series of menus, with confusing abbreviations and volcabulary if you're not already familiar with scientific notation and units of measurement. If the menus were a bit more friendly I think it would open up this game to alot more people. The actual simulation field can be a bother to wrangle too. I found it sometimes likes to snap focus to nearly every other celestial body but the one I want to focus on. The "searchbar" at the top ended up being my best friend.          If youre like me, and you can wrangle the menus and put up with the sometimes sketchy simulation, it truely is a universe at your fingertips. This simulator will only take you as far as your imagination (or processor) will take you. Binary systems, rings around Earth -- have you ever wondered what it would look like if the earth had a ring then the moon crashed through it?  The possiblities are more or less limitless, given your computer can handle the math. If youre into astronomy, physics or just enjoy space to any degree, this game is worth checking out.         Without an actual objectives or things to accomplish, this game falls short of actually being a game. It would be better described as an app. This one probably isnt right for the masses, but just right for the armchair astronomer in me.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												Universe Sandbox is exactly what its name implies: a place for you to play around with astronomical bodies and see how changing various things will effect the macro-universe. I think it is one of the most unique and awesome titles on Steam. It is well put together, the physics in the game accurately demonstrate real-life laws, and the recent update that puts you directly into a tutorial the first time you start the game really helps you figure out the, at first intimidating amount of, options that you can play around with.Whether for work, play, or educational purposes, Universe Sandbox is an excellent title that I don't think any Steam account should lack. If you have *any* interest, even a minute amount, in astronomy, physics, or even if you ever wondered what would happen to Saturn's rings if Neptune flew too close, you need to have this game. It's very relaxing to play with, and the the engine is extremely deep - allowing you to truly let your imagination run wild. The GUI is clean and efficient, and the pre-built simulations and environments are extremely well put together and fun to play with.  Some examples include:*Environments:*Our Solar SystemLocal GalaxiesEarth & MoonSaturn & Moons*Physics Playgrounds:*Small Scale GravityFloating MoonsGalaxy CollisionBuy now, build your own galaxy or satellite system, and watch what happens as time passes and you introduce variables into the equation.*Bonus:* You can smash an asteroid into Earth to see what would happen, awesome for those bad days at the office.

number of helpful: 121 of 135 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Universe Sandbox isn't a game per se; there are no bosses, aims or levels, merely an accurate model of astronomical bodies for you to fiddle with. It's really more of a toy – the virtual equivalent of a configurable orrery, except hugely more complex than any mechanical system.That complexity is one of the key attractions that Universe Sandbox possesses. Using the vast range of variables and tools at your disposal you can create some enormously convoluted displays of physics, bending cosmic laws to your will out of nothing more than a desire to see pretty patterns form on your screen.There are a series of example experiments to help ease you into the level of curiosity that Universe Sandbox requires – each one acting as a tutorial – but the real fun lies in creating your own simulations. The camera is a little fiddly at times, but my biggest complaint is that the simulator doesn’t come with any sound or music. While I appreciate that’s realistic, given the lack of orchestras in the vacuum of space, it would have been nice to have some ambient music quietly twinkling away in the background.Still, it’s hard to get too dissatisfied with Universe Sandbox when you factor in both the fact that it’s a one-man labour of love and that it’s available at a bargain price. If nothing else it offers something uniquely interesting and fun, which is quick to inspire imagination and creativity, even if it lacks the educational aspect that you might expect.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												This is one of those meta-sim-sandbox-edu-tutorial-discovery games that are so common these days, but it's still tough to explain what you can actually DO, if not what it actually IS, so let me try to explain with a brief anecdote.   Years ago, my kids wanted a dog.  They begged for some unspecified period of time, until one day we were driving along and saw a 'free puppy' sign at a farm.  We stopped, and wound up taking home what the farmer told us was a 'purebred Welsh Olive Hound'.  Thing is, when we took it to the vet for shots, we found out it was actually a toaster oven.     I guess what I'm trying to say is that Universe Sandbox looks like a game, but it's a lot more like a toaster oven.  Everyone should have one, but it won't be fetching you any sticks.

Product received for free
												In Universe Sandbox you create universes consisting of planets, stars and galaxies. If you struggle creating a universe you can choose to run various solar system templates that can help you build your own.Starting this game for the first time I was overwhelmed with the complexity and detail the developers at Giant Army put into this simulation game, usually with the genre you see a rushed physics engine and incompletegame but this game there is no sign of that. content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I've got to say, Universe Sandbox is unique in a lot of ways. I can't recall a single game that allows you to manipulate gravity and time so easily, though this is wasted on me. Smashing things into other things is fun c: But I digress. Universe Sandbox is a great simulator, but is it a game? You need a good deal of imagination to get any more than a few hours of fun out of this, because there are very few game mechanics involved. Can you increase the mass of the Sun and watch the effect on the solar system? Indeed! Does this do anything? Not really, it just shows you what happens.If you think you'd enjoy exploring some of the finer orbital mechanics that KSP never taught you, then you might like Universe Sandbox. I'm recommending it because it's a pretty damn good simulation, but it isn't for everyone. Aside from the few tutorials demonstrating things you could do, it's mostly... well, a sandbox! That means there's almost no reward from dumping hours into the game other than satisfying curiosity that couldn't be soothed elsewhere.

number of helpful: 88 of 162 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Universe Sandbox shouldn't be looked at with the expectation of a game. It's exactly what it says it is, a sandbox on a universal scale, but to be used for teaching and experimentation purposes far more than simply to entertain (though perhaps some may find enjoyment over manipulating galaxies). It does an excellent job at what it attempts, but is hard to recommend to anyone but the most avid space lover for its dry and overly open ended nature.If you're still unclear what US actually is, you can think of it as playing god with stars and planets in a galaxy of your own design. You're given complete free reign over every aspect of your universe and all that's within it, allowing you to create scenarios that could never occur in reality but nonetheless I'm sure many have wondered what would look like (for example: what if the earth was the size of the sun). It's an intriguing idea with nearly limitless options, but I have to take issue with US for doing a poor job catering to anyone but those who already posses a keen understanding of the cosmos and a fascination with what they hold. Aside from a few tutorial sections that show you a few possible things you can do, you're left to create your own fun, which for some (myself included) doesn't go much farther than shooting a dozen planet size footballs into the sun and seeing what comes of it.I can't recommend Universe Sandbox to many, but it's not because it's bad or too much along the lines of taking an astronomy class. It knows what it is and gives you all the tools you could want to fool around in a galaxy, testing possible outcomes or teaching others about what exists in the vastness of space, but it will only ever appeal to a niche audience of astrophysicists and those that simply have a deep love of space. It's a tool that gives back whatever you put into it, the problem is just knowing how to use it.

number of helpful: 14 of 23 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
 Overview  Universe Sandbox is a gravity and space simulator with a heavy focus on player control, interaction and experimentation. The game allows for scale simulations of our galaxy, planets, stars, moons and those of any number of known galaxies as well. There aren't too many limitations with the game, as it has gone through several revisions over many, many years. Universe Sandbox first started out as an educational project back in or around 1993 by a single developer named Dan Dixon. The project then went through two revisions before version 2.1 was released on Steam in May of 2010 for sale.The game itself doesn't have a beginning, middle or end. There is no story to tell, no narration to follow, but that doesn't leave it feeling hollow. Universe Sandbox gives you the tools and abilities to craft your own universe, make your own planets and create something that is really all your own...or collide them together and watch them explode for the sheer reason that you can. The game leaves those decisions up to you.Not everyone will enjoy this game. I feel that it is a very niche title that might cater to those who enjoy simulation experiments, math, space enthusiasts, or those that just have an appreciation of taking something anyway from a game that is more than just fun. I originally picked up Universe Sandbox because I love space related games and I'd love to have a method to simulate what I've learned and continue to read about on my own.The meat of Universe Sandbox is based on what you make of it. When you first start, you'll be greeted by a tutorial that will show you various aspects of the game, where to go and what you can do. The tutorial felt a little minimal and I felt like it lacked depth. There are pre-defined simulations with objectives that you can play to help familiarize yourself with the UI and I felt those helped a lot. However, the overall presentation could use some polish.When it comes to actually building solar systems, crashing planets, exploding suns and or freezing the earth (take that global warming! ^_-) or any of the numerous godlike powers it's enjoyable, but I felt like it was lacking in...something. It's hard to say what that feeling was and I honestly couldn't tell you still, but building creations on a galaxy scale still felt marginal in scope. I remember building my own galaxy with planets, stars, a sun, whatever I felt it needed and when I was done, I was done. I wasn't really sure where I went from there; compare it to a model airplane. Once my model was finished, I had nothing to do. I could do another, but the outcome was the same.I wanted a model airplane I could touch; I wanted something tangible. However, Universe Sandbox is not tangible. I cannot pick it up off the shelf and admire it. That, most of all, was what I felt the game was missing. It lacked purpose. Would I recommended it? Yes, absolutely, but only to those who know what you're getting. As I mentioned earlier in this review, I feel the game caters to a small audience. Some players will hate it, some will love it and some will fall somewhere in the middle like I did.  Pros   Customization - There's an infinite amount of ways to change your simulation. Your limit is your imagination.  Tutorials - There's quite a few to help get you use to the UI and how the game functions, especially for those that don't have a lot of knowledge with space-related terms. You learn. Whether it be about the physical properties of our universe or the math behind the science, you'll come away with something new. Cons    The UI can be rather clunky when setting up experiments or simulations (other than pre-developed ones) Achievements - They are odd and will require a guide to unlock some of them. One is purely ridiculous, which requires you to run the game for an entire year (total, not in one sitting). Good luck! .-. There is no music. Some may prefer that, but I didn't care for the silence. There is no sound in space, but I felt there should have been in the game.Overall, I like Universe Sandbox. It won't tug at your heart strings, nor give you a story to tell your friends. There is no plot, there are no boss fights, no method in which to level up; there's just you, gravity and the infinite possibilities in your mind. If you like the idea of building a world, watching it wiz by the dark void of space and then finally colliding with a neighboring planet because you scaled back the mass, then Universe Sandbox might be for you. If that doesn't interest you, then I would recommend you spend your money elsewhere.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												What was a good idea at first turned out to be a very mediocre "solar system sim" educational game that is better off as a free CD somewhere at the back of 5th Grade Astronomy textbook. The Physics model is extremely flawed, so is the engine optimisation. Even if you have the full solar system model running in the sim, eventually Mercury will slingshot itself towards Andromeda Galaxy because, and I'm assuming here, it's actually an alien spaceship and it was performing an orbital maneuver in order to speed up (hello, Rama). That was sarcasm by the way. Anyway, In a game like this one there should be at least the ability to create your own stars/planets, and not just select pre-existing ones, a bigger variety of space objects would be welcome.You should have the ability to see the internal structure of each celestial body, just like in some of the App Store apps like StarWalk or SolarWalk. This isn't 1996, there should be many many MANY more options, including the ability to see every single man-made satellite or mission, also all of the satellites currently in orbit and proper models for them in addition to real photos/maps of each planet and star, not just links to wikipedia.As always, metacritic gives this an unfairly high score. Make no mistake, this sim is a huge disappointment. The selling point of this game is realism and the gravitational model is broken, making this piece of software as useless as a helicopter in outer space.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Holy crap.  For an application with no goals, no formal "game" aspect to it at all, this is amazingly fun.  I've just gotten started and I am already compiling a massive list of "what would happen if" scenarios with regards to celestial physics.  I've always been a bit of an amateur astronomy nerd and Universe Sandbox plays to that predeliction, so it may not be for everyone.  As yet it's also pretty buggy.  But part of what I love so much about projects like this are the potentially sea-changing implications for educational processes.  This makes a part of science that takes centuries for humans to actually observe fully interactive over the course of a few minutes.  Gives me chills.  We live in a brave, new world my friends.  Revel in it now.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Are you curious about how space works?  The secrets of the universe something that interests you? Or have you wanted to wield the power of a god, destroying planets and galaxies alike? If any of those are true then this is the game/ education tool for you.It’s a simple game; you get to run simulations from the minuscule to the galactic. It is a ton of fun and I learnt a few things from it too. But as you would expect I did it just to destroy planets. That being said I find it easy to recommend for anyone who wants to learn more about the universe.With a huge library of available experiments to choose from and the ability to create your own using the massive amount of custom options the game offers to you for almost everything I had a lot of fun running simulations and just relaxing.Fully priced I would have a hard time recommending this title, especially with the better and more updated sequel already on steam but on sale this is a fun little distraction that will help answer a few of those nagging questions in the back of your mind.Have fun ^_^

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I've always loved space and anything to with it, so trying out Universe Sandbox was a fun, educational experience.If you like space and the universe, physics simulators, and experimenting with different variables in space, then you will really enjoy this game.The aesthetics are great - it's your own solar system/galaxy/universe simulator, complete with stars, suns, etc. You can zoom in and out a great deal, and slow or speed up the real-time by a few minutes, days, years, etc. One of the coolest things to play around with is the different rings - you can add planetary rings to everything, and experiment with mass/velocity to watch how these variables influence the ring patterns. You can also toggle different colors to represent things in the universe like acceleration/velocity, mass, etc (the planetary bodies will trail different colors depending on what you select). Reflecting the realities of space, there is no sound or music, however, I didn't really mind (playing my own is perfectly fine).The controls are simple, you just click on the variety of options available; however, understanding what each option can do may take some time to fully appreciate. The learning curve is minimal to moderate - the numerous options may itimidate people who do not understand basic physics (since this is a physics simulator in space), but the video tutorials are very helpful in getting you familiarized with each functions. There is also a list of fun things to do in the sidebar, which will offer you a step-by-step blueprint of how to achieve things like adding planetary rings to the Earth's moon and seeing how gravity effects it (very nice visuals if you try this out).Of course, one of the first things I did while trying this out was to increase Earth's velocity and force it out of orbit - hurtling through space and turning black from freezing over. You can add moons or asteroids, turn things into black holes, and manipulate factors like velocity, mass, etc. I tried dropping moons into Earth, however, it appears to make the planet larger (as if it absorbs them). I do not know how to crash them into each other yet (or if that's even possible). With the large amount of variables you can manipulate, there is good number of things you can do and experiment with in the vastness of space.Overall, if you have the least bit of interest in physics and/or space, then you should definitely give this game a try. Recommend!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												Being a goddess is a pretty normal thing for me, but controlling the planets is new. You pretty quickly discover that anything in orbit is in an unstable state of affairs, and almost any change you make, even moving Venus ever so slightly further from Mars,  results in death and destruction on a Biblical scale. Luckily death is often so fast your six billion minions on earth barely get time to see the bright flash or tidal wave before they are knocking at the pearly gates, but after you have learnt that one fact a dozen different ways; that death comes easy and quick, and the population of earth are getting a little sick of being resurrected only to face certain annihilation, then I think the simulation really does fall a bit flat. It needs more. What, I am not sure. Maybe some goddessly music, I dunno, but as it stands it’s a five minute wonder. Recommended? No, I am afraid not.

The creation of a new solar system is entertaining, but most assuredly could be helped by a slightly better UI where you can do more configuration to get your star system started (i.e. binary stars, setting orbits, and the like) but for the price, this is both an educational tool that even those familiar with the science could find revealing and a plaything for those that just want to drop a red dwarf star on top of pluto to see what happens.

Posted: August 29, 2014
												Universe Sandbox is a sandbox simulation of celestial bodies and should be taken as it is. You may not get the usual youtube-fodder-laughter-inducing effects from this as with other "simulation" games (although you may if you enjoy destroying universe while laughing evilly). I certainly can't comment the physics as I don't have the competency to do so, but I have some expectancy of visual detail not fulfilled by the engine. Visual effects are pretty bland. UI is pretty cluttery and need some time to familiarize with. It does have high level of complexity, it keep tracks of many parameters, such as velocity, mass, density, and temperature, and did a great job simulating it.In conclusion, Universe Sandbox falls more on an educational tool than a game, it even has in-game wikipedia browser. It is enjoyable for space nerds like me, and a good education tool, though I suggest to wait for its more awesome sequel.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Its hard to reccomend this game because although this is an excelent little physics "game" its not a "game". There arent goals beyond the tutorials (unless you count the achievements). Its a game similar to garrys mod where you have to make your own fun. It does have an active steam comunity constantly putting out new universes for you to explore and its great at accidentaly teaching you about the way the great big nothing works. I would whole heartedly recomend this game to anyone who has an interest in space but its not for everyone. After that its well worth the price tag no matter the price. Just dont go into it expecting goals or missions. Im enjoying this alot and If you like math and space then you will too. 9/10.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												I have spend a couple hours in this game and already I feel as if I've done all that I can do.  I've created the apocolypse a douzen different ways, I've shot hundreds of oversized teapots at the sun, and created black holes which eat up the galaxy.  But unfortunately, though this sounds like a blast, this game fails to deliver on many fronts.  I'd like to just say right now that this isn't a bad... game?  I use the term 'game' lightly because it really is more of a simulation sandbox, just as the title suggests.  My main problem with Universe Sandbox was the target audience.  The game's controls are made to be straightforward enough so that anyone can get the hang of them pretty quickly, but some of the details require some moderate scientific knowledge.  I feel as if this program has the potential to be a either a fun game or an amusing scientific program, but the developers seem to have created something in between the two.  The gameplay itself is smooth and enjoyable in moderation, but there isn't enough content or mechanics to keep the average player interested for more than maybe 45 minutes to an hour.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												It's pretty fun to see different parts of space and see either how they work without messing with them, but the best part is seeing how you can change things and overtime how that would change the universe. There are some built in interesting scenarios, like the solar system, the collision of Andromeda and the Milky Way, and I think there are a few others I can't remember. You can change the size or density of certain objects, introduce new objects, and just generally play god with the universe. There aren't a million things to do, unless you want to do the same things in every area you see, but it is definitely fun to just see it and learn how it all works. It's like physics and astronomy class put into practice.One thing that came to mind was that when I was interested in achievements, this game has completely unobtainable and irrelevant achievements. There all time played based and it's things like play for a day, play for a week, play for a month, etc. I think there are some other ones, and you can get some ideas of things to do from that. Of course steam achievements are useless and there's no way to track them, so it doesn't matter unless you really absolutely need to get 100% achievements in all the games you play.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I have a degree in astrophysics and I must say this is a fun tool to play with. In a normal work of astrophysicist you'd have to program all this stuff by yourself - here you have everything what you need - models, integrator and visualisation tool.But honestly this is not for everyone. Of course it is fun to throw asteroid into earth, change the Sun into a black hole or compare sizes of nearby stars. I'd say it's about 20 minutes of fun. After that this tool would be thrown away and never run again.I'd say this tool is dedicated for people really interested in math and astrophysics. You really need an idea what you want to simulate and spend some time to work on the initial conditions. For me a real fun was to see what happens to predefined rings of Saturns, when you insert Earth-mass moon on an elongated orbit. Amazing how the rings transform - I even saw some kind of density waves there. I feel that some very complicated differential equations must make the physics there.Some people complain that when you speed up you get unrealiable results. Of course. Unfortunately implemented integrator is not very sophisticated and loses accuracy quickly. This is why you have accuracy measure available. When you get into yellow or red domain you are no longer watching physics but numerical artifacts. This can be entertaining too. But if you want realiable results you will have to wait a long time depending on the complexity of the problem. Patience is a must in any computer modelling.To sumarize - you really need to know what you are doing to have fun from this program.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I simply cannot recommend this "game" because I feel as if it was meant for teaching. I do not have much time into it because I cannot keep myself entertained. Sure, if you know absolutely everything about space physics, units and so on then I'm sure you can get a few hours out of this. However, upon entering the game, I was bombarded with loads of sub-menus, most of which I had no idea what to do. And yes, I did some of the tutorials, but a game is simply not enjoyable to me when you have to do several tutorials or know a lot about certain subjects.It fails to deliver an entertaining experience, as it was simply built to please space enthusiasts. It feels like a cheap program that could be used in a classroom, nothing more.There is also the fact that the game has already crashed/errored out for me a few times, simply by just experimenting with different physics, which is what the game is meant to do...Did I mention that the game also has no sound? That makes it even more dull.For this I would say just save your money unless it goes on sale for a dollar.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												This sandbox is pretty neat. You can either choose to take existing systems in the universe and play around with them or create your own from scratch. It's not strictly speaking a game. but if you've read the info about it, you shouldn't really have that impression. It's nice to play around with and see what you can do by adding in bizarre elements to all sorts of galactic scenarios (a giant teapot appears, hurtling through space towards the Solar System! It is 30 times the size of the sun! Oh dear...). It provides some amusing little elements such as this, as well as the opportunity to build your own working systems (a real challenge!).If this sandbox really appeals to you, buy it! If you just have a mild interest in space and think it might be fun to try out, perhaps wait for a sale.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												I am not sure what I was expecting... a sandbox universe... sounds fun. But after the tutorial, and a few of the built-in scenarios I think I've pretty much seen it all. Its basically not much more than a gravity simulator where you can vary the size, speed position of some objects and watch how they collide... Maybe my lack of creativity is to blame, but the unintuitive controls of this "game" are not exactly helpful either...I bet there are tons flash browser apps out there that can show you the same thing with slightly less fancy graphics.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												I love solar system builder games, but this one lacks features that you would expect. A good solar system builder would give you a little more freedom and creative options. I bought this game thinking it would allow you to edit planets atmosphere colors and material makeup and interesting things like that, instead it gives you predesigned planets, like Earth and Mars. The physics work quite well and its pretty cool to watch stars eat each other but It gets boring in minutes. One major issue is that the game lacks a soundtrack. There is no noise in the game that I know of. I got so bothered by the lack of sound that I had to play some Operation Ivy afterwards to get my head straight. Currently, I am waiting for my refund and  will drop my money on a game like Deus Ex or some other classic game like that. DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME. IT'S NOT WORTH YOUR TIME.-Edit. If it's on sale, for a very low price, go for it. I feel like this game would be better off as a 99 cents game on mobile devices.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												This is one of those times that I wish Steam offered a "mediocre" choice for ranking games that was somewhere in between "thumbs up" and "thumbs down".  Because that's this game -- it is what it is: a space sandbox sim.  So why not a "thumbs up" then, you ask?  Well, you COULD pay $10 for this game...or you COULD instead download NASA/JPL's Eyes On The Solar System app for FREE (and which is very similar to, and just as good as, Universe Sandbox).  While Universe Sandbox might offer more functions/options, Eyes On The Solar System seems to win in the scientific accuracy department and also has better visuals.  So, to sum up, it's not that Universe Sandbox is terrible; It's just that it's not that great for $10, when comparable programs are available for no charge.  I couldn't honestly recommend that someone spend money on this.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Ce programme est un simulateur d'espace temps. Il n'est pas simplement adapté qu'aux astrophysiciens en herbes, mais aussi conçu, je l'imagine pour ceux qui oseraient tenter l'expérience d'une anticipation cataclysmique de notre tendre et chère planète, voire de l'univers, pourquoi pas. Et si le soleil devenait une géante rouge en dix minutes par exemple ? Une supernova ? Une nébuleuse ?la question que tout le monde se pose, dont le résultat serait vérifiable dans 5 milliards d'années, environ.Vérifiable par qui d'ailleurs ?Je n'ai pas encore testé l'expérience, mais c'est certainement la première chose que je vais tenter de simuler. Enfin, si le programme le permet !A première vue, ce simulateur offre de nombreuses possibilités. Dont beaucoup peuvent être assez désastreuses.Alors profitez en, tout n'est que virtuel.Pour le moment :)

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I was dissapointed in this simulation because it was not what I was looking for. Mere minutes after installing I could see how simple it was and not what I needed.  What I mean by 'simple' is that when I zoomed in one of Saturn's moons, not only was it the same texture used as every other moon, but what really bugged me was that it did not rotate properly. The exact same face would be always in shadow, when I know that though tidally locked, one face always points to Saturn, the entire surface should be lighted by the sun as it rotates around its primary planet. Also, it refused to load my own textures on the various worlds, even though there was a place for the files ... it would not load. I wish I could get a refund for this.I don't normally write reviews but I was directed to this program by a recommendation online and I was underwhelmed.  Maybe U^2 will be better.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												It's not stable. If you speed up the game it breaks. However if you load another file with a thousand objects flying at much higher speeds no problem. Apparently the game has different modes that enable for heavier simulations, but I'm not sure you can use that more stable mode yourself.I've also had it crash making me lose my progress. First crash was within 20 seconds on a very stable pc.The game only takes very little resources of your pc. So I was sitting here with a nice i7, 8GB ram and a GTX-750 looking at non-fullscreen low-fps simulations of the universe. Sigh.UI isn't great, background is very low-res or out of focus. No ambient music. Game is unstable...It's still fun I guess, but I expected much more.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I was dissapointed in this simulation because it was not what I was looking for. Mere minutes after installing I could see how simple it was and not what I needed.  What I mean by 'simple' is that when I zoomed in one of Saturn's moons, not only was it the same texture used as every other moon, but what really bugged me was that it did not rotate properly. The exact same face would be always in shadow, when I know that though tidally locked, one face always points to Saturn, the entire surface should be lighted by the sun as it rotates around its primary planet. Also, it refused to load my own textures on the various worlds, even though there was a place for the files ... it would not load. I wish I could get a refund for this.I don't normally write reviews but I was directed to this program by a recommendation online and I was underwhelmed.  Maybe U^2 will be better.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												It's not stable. If you speed up the game it breaks. However if you load another file with a thousand objects flying at much higher speeds no problem. Apparently the game has different modes that enable for heavier simulations, but I'm not sure you can use that more stable mode yourself.I've also had it crash making me lose my progress. First crash was within 20 seconds on a very stable pc.The game only takes very little resources of your pc. So I was sitting here with a nice i7, 8GB ram and a GTX-750 looking at non-fullscreen low-fps simulations of the universe. Sigh.UI isn't great, background is very low-res or out of focus. No ambient music. Game is unstable...It's still fun I guess, but I expected much more.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												For those who are interested in space, astrology and science as a whole this game is a massively enjoyable piece of software! For those who want to be shooting or flying about in a spaceship, this really isn't what you're looking for.For the few pounds that I paid for it in the sale it is well worth the spend, and can provide hours of gameplay, despite becomming a little dull at times. The game is simply what you make of it; a more creative player will certainly find this more enjoyable since the content is generated from the unlimited number of scenarios that you can create. For those who aren't so imagniative, the game provides a good sample of ready-made scenarios and oddities to explore.As for the playability of the game, some of the menus can be confusing, and so I would reccomend taking the tutorial! The 'camera' controls are easy to use and have the adequate range of movement and precision necessary to be intuitive.TLDR:Good for sciencey people, has excellent controls and a wide range of things to do! It's a game but also useful for learning!Bad for those who want an action packed game with explosions etc.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												As others have noted, this simulator cannot even simulate correctly.  The devs are sloppy coders who don't know how to do proper bounds checking, as evidenced by objects randomly flying off into space if the simulation is sped up.   You would think that they would have detected this and fixed it by now, but none such is the case.  Careless and sloppy.I wouldn't even recommend this as a tutorial for grade school kids, either, because of the inaccurate and unpredictable results when tweaking parameters (which is supposed to be 99% of the usefulness of this program in the first place). What's more, the devs have decided to add an "atmospheric warming due to CO2 level"  parameter to their new version.  In order for this to be credible, the mathematical model employed would need to be disclosed (which I seriously doubt will  happen).  But, regardless of whether they do, they have decided to go against 50,000+ scientists who are on record as stating that human-produced CO2 is NOT the cause of global warming. It is a hoax promulgated by NWO globalists and their sock puppets like Al Gore.   There is overwhelming evidence to the contrary now -- which is that climate cycles are simply linked to solar cycles. So, I am disappointed that Dan Dixon and his ragtag team of devs have chosen to subscribe to the non-scientific, mainstream media propaganda, which is funded by the globalists, with the intention of hoodwinking the world into thinking that a global carbon tax is necessary to "save" the planet.   They are doing a terrible disservice to young people by reinforcing the brainwashing in this regard.  And it is for this reason that I will permanently boycott all future products from this company.(Note: Acquired via a bundle)

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												It's a fun idea but the simulator has a lot less freedom than you might think in designing your own universe setups.There are (very) limited palettes of preset bodies to choose from. Given, you can change the individual properties of the presets if you really want to, but that quickly becomes an exercise in numbers and is far from as much fun as it is advertised as.Another strong negative point of the sim is its accuracy/speed. The simulation is neither accurate nor speedy, and you will very quickly end up with horrendous frame rates and/or woefully inaccurate trajectories that would make any 1st year physics student cringe. Yes, I have a fast processor, no it doesn't help.Definitely not recommended, you'd better spend your money on something that is either more useful or more fun.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												The game is supposed to be a physics simulator, but if I use it as anything but a screen saver it crashes.  Even just running the Earth and Moon scenario where you have literally TWO BODIES to deal with, the program slows and dies.  It's already crashed several times and I haven't even had the game for an hour.  As others mention, the controls and layout aren't very smooth, and if time is sped up the objects just go flying off.  It is nothing like the trailer.  Once the game starts to crash, there is no recovery, the controls become inverted if they respond at all.  The zoom feature seems broken as well which makes the program even more difficult to operate.  Trying to change angles or move throughout is supposed to be what the whole game is about to get a visual and it can't even do this smoothly.This game isn't finished, it needs some serious bug fixes.  It's an interesting idea that is being poorly executed.

This game offers you a lot though, you can see physics in macro form, i.e. check what would happen to our planetary system  if Sun's mass was different. This game is not bad and has huge potential, but I'd recommend it to enthusiast of astrophysisc rather to gamers who are not into that kind of scientific things.

												Sim is ok, but this game/sim has a few of the MOST STUPIDIEST achievements in all games i have played.. When you have to guess something what you maybe never knew or when the description is misleading.. Well the one when you have to run this program for 12 months is on the edge too.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												It's not really a game, it's space object/matter physics simulator. You can create moons, rings, planets, suns, blackholes, explode objects, change mass, velocity and a edit some more relevant statistics and watch chaos unfold, but I actually found it behaving oddly sometimes and my experience didn't go much farther than experimenting odd scenarios before getting bored.Also beware Achievement hunters/completists, there's at least 2 achievments that are absurdly hard to get, one is execute the game 10 000 times and another one that is run the game for 1 year, that's roughly 8760 hours! Not being able to get the achivement and be able to enjoy other games in less than 1 year is really bothering me.In short, this isn't much of a game, there's no objectives or goals, just experimentation, this isn't for everyone and I'm sure there may be a target audience for this but while interesting for the novelty, my feelings are, if given the chance to go back in time, I wouldn't pay for it again, and as such, I don't recommend this "game".

content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												I'm a big nerd and an astrophysics freak. This "simulation", is disappointing to me in alot of ways. Horrible interface, buggy and unstable as hell, and poorly executed on the whole. Don't read into bragging that it does... it is no where near as ground breaking or interesting as it claims to be. The whole draw of being able to collide galaxies and planets loses it's appeal when you actually do it and realise that the planets break apart into smaller planets, and that pretty much every barren world in our solarsystem has the same skin as our moon.If you want a good sandbox game in the universe, then "Space Engine" is your best options. Sure you can't play pool with crappy looking, unrealistic planets, but it looks fantastic, you can explore many things and it's free.

												My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. 												I played this game for not too long, I picked it up in a humble bundle and when I played it I was expecting something similar to Solar 2 which is a game that I really enjoyed because of its odd rpg planet elements. This game isn't like that, it is a simulator game where you are given our solar system and you are able to change the attributes of the planets like planet mass and orbit. The other thing that put me off about the game was the achievements, as someone who enjoys collecting achievements the idea of starting up this game 10,000 times was off putting. This is a game that is good at what it does, but I don't like what it does, but if you are a astronomy buff who wants to see what would happen if Pluto gained enough mass to be more than a dwarf then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												Create and destroy on a scale you’ve never imagined with the ultimate space simulator. Harness the power to create black holes, collide galaxies, and manipulate gravity with just a few clicks. Inspired by the software astronomers use to unlock the mysteries of our universe, never before has astronomy been so interactive or so much fun. Spawn a massive moon to tear apart Saturn’s rings or launch a rogue star to rip the planets from their orbits around our sun. After unleashing catastrophic destruction, create your own solar system and share it with friends.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												This game is a great piece of edutainment. The dev previously made a promise however that if you buy this game, you'll get an upgrade to it at a later date, and the dev recently went back on that. I might add that it was for a good reason however, he provided it free of charge to any school district that wants it. I wouldn't mind buying the next update (really a ground up rewrite for more accuracy as well as more tools.) The "game" which is hardly a game, and really software, simulates how various things work in our solar system. It also gives you the tools to make another from scratch. It's seriously neat to play with, though there are some accuracy bugs when you move past a certain speed. All in all, if you happen to like space, or ask yourself "what would happen if I altered the orbit of the moon ever so slightly" then this is the software for you.

Posted: June 16, 2014
												This is possibly the coolest tool you could give someone interested in space.  There is only one problem with it, and that deals with the math dealing with the acceleration of objects occuring when you up the time scale.  For instance; you will launch Earth's Moon beyong Jupiter if you want to see the Earth and Moon in thier positions a few years in the future.  Unless you wait (a really long time) the increased "speed" of time becomes the speed of the objects being modified in the simulation.  Otherwise?Otherwise, the game is an awesome simulator for physics in a zero gravity vacuum.  Several objects are available for you to play with: Dice, bowling balls, planets, singularities, the speed the earth rotates. . . . This list could be really ridiculous.  If you have had a bad day, you could launch the Earth into the sun. (Achievement alert)Now, If you will excuse me, I am going to resume my simulation of the Death Star orbiting Endor.

Posted: February 17, 2014
												Crashes way too often. Not properly multithreaded. It runs such low FPS even though not using even 50% of CPU nor GPU. A bit lacking on camera controls and game mechanics etc. The concept is fantastic and while you don't do anything and just watch, the game is quite breathtaking. Once you try to get involved, however, you constantly feel like something's missing; whether it be the ability to undo actions or rewind the game so you can watch a different collision. Simple things like trying to pause the simulation can become frustrating if you're editing game values such as the speed of the game because instead of pausing, pressing spacebar is locked to typing so you literally can't pause untill you press escape a bunch of times. It's all little things but there's so many little things that are annoying and plain disabling from the experience. I find this game enjoyable to watch (assuming it doesn't crash every 15 minutes), but difficult to 'play'.Win7 Ultimate 64-biti5 4670k @ 3.8Ghz16GB RAMGTX 770

												Ever want to create your own solar system? Galaxy? Universe? Then get this game. You can open up pre-made saves, like our own solar system, or even two galaxies colliding. Or you can start from scratch. Place a star, then add a few planets, some asteroids, and even a couple dice if you want. Yep. Dice. You can take an object and turn it into a black hole. Heck, you can send a meteor into Earth, or drive Earth into Betelgeuse (its a star), or...well you get the picture. The possibilities are endless. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who likes the stars, total freedom, and creating absolute chaos.

Posted: July 7, 2011
												Astronomy is something everyone is atleast a little interested in at some point.Universe Sandbox is just that; a sandbox. Create amazing backdrops of galaxies from your imagination, solar systems you've seen on TV, make many planets circle each other in a beautiful symbiotic orbi- SMASH EVERYTHING.USandbox gives an amazing amount of freedom to bring the universe and all it's physics to it's pitiful little knees. Warp those galaxies, create super-massive black holes to suck every little asteroid into it's singularity-future. The graphical and mathmatical demands on your computer can be taxing at times (>250 galaxies into one cataclysmic result) but oh what a beautiful sight it is to behold. Not a game as such, the achievements are more jokes than anything - but the time-based ones are very possible once you realize how fun it is being -god-.(Also, the 3D options and customization are out of this world - literally..)

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Universe Sandbox is exactly what its namesake implies. You have the ability to play around with heavenly bodies and change parameters that make them move in strange or unique ways. A word of warning, though: Even the beefiest of gaming rigs can become taxed if the simulation is complex, because this game is making many physical calculations simultaneously.My only complaint about the game is that it only follows classical Newtonian mechanics. It doesn't account for relativistic effects. For example, I have been able to eject a planet from a solar system at 10c, or ten times the speed of light, but in real life that's physically impossible.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												I bought this game a long time ago, when it was first offered on Steam and have to admit, I thought it too difficult at the time. It required more thinking than I wanted to do, my "day job" taking way too much out of me to come home and have to think instead of play. BUT - I recently crashed my system and after getting Steam back online I opened the game to discover it had a LOT of new options, (3D Nvidia support for one), and I decided to try it again. Since I no longer have a job, (disabled), this title is exactly what I need to ensure my brain doesn't atrophy! I also love astronomy, use my awesome telescope, weather permitting, and tried to create a solar system with mixed results. Graphics: Round planets are still faceted, but only when seen close up. Colors are vivid or muted, depending on the reality and settings, and the realism setting brings one away from our solar system to observe the paths and orbits of moons I, personally, didn't know were out there. Difficulty: Yep, it is still a complex game, but guess what? Playing God will give one a greater appreciation of His occupational stress levels...solar systems are amazingly complicated and the physics behind a simple retune of the moon's orbit about the Earth requires more than I can manage on paper-thank the makers of Intel and Nvidia for doing it for me. FunFactor: I would give this a "10" overall, and the fun factor is even more! I intend to be up all night creating my personal solar system and once done I will post it wherever it is you do that. No, I cannot explain much, read the manual, check the website, do the research and have FUN, the rewards far outstrip the labor and even the labor is fun if you have an interest in all things space related. (If not, why would you even consider this game?) Well worth the price of admission and time spent to use it as the sandbox universe construction toolbox it is.

Posted: February 1, 2014
												Let me preface my review with this statement: Universe Sandbox is NOT a game, or at least not in any real, traditional sense. Now that I got that out of the way, I think that Universe Sandbox is indeed fun yet educational & should be in everyone's Steam library, especially if you have at least a mild interest in space, physics, and/or from time to time asked yourself miscellaneous "what if..." questions. Ever wonder what things would be like if you crushed our sun into a black hole? Ever wanted to see multiple black holes orbit each other? Want to recreate Tantooine with it's twin suns? Well, you can find out (or do) all that and more with Universe Sandbox. All in all it's just plain ol' fun to just screw around with, and seeing as there's real science & physics behind it, you just may learn something while doing so.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												"Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there--on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds.Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known."-- Carl Sagan, Pale Blue Dot, 1994

Posted: December 22, 2012
												Do you space?  If you buy this game you can space until you space and then space inside of space until space is space and you are spacing in space.  On a more serious note if you have ever been curious about gravitational pull and how finely-tuned the solar system is, this is a wonderful program to mess with it and see just how boned we are if the sun ever decides to just straight-up disappear.    If you hate werewolves you can blow up the moon.  Boom.  No more werewolves; that's half of the twilight problem solved.You can decide to say "Screw you Jupiter, get out of here I hate you!" because Jupiter's gotten too fat and is doing nothing but loafing around outside the asteroid belt.  However afterwards you might realise you kind of miss Jupiter because suddenly everything's gone a little too wonky and you just want to go back to the good old days of orbiting carelessly around the sun until the sun gets tired of your♥♥♥♥♥♥or some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ celestial-body decides to barge on in and ruin everything. Posted: July 7, 2011
												Astronomy is something everyone is atleast a little interested in at some point.Universe Sandbox is just that; a sandbox. Create amazing backdrops of galaxies from your imagination, solar systems you've seen on TV, make many planets circle each other in a beautiful symbiotic orbi- SMASH EVERYTHING.USandbox gives an amazing amount of freedom to bring the universe and all it's physics to it's pitiful little knees. Warp those galaxies, create super-massive black holes to suck every little asteroid into it's singularity-future. The graphical and mathmatical demands on your computer can be taxing at times (>250 galaxies into one cataclysmic result) but oh what a beautiful sight it is to behold. Not a game as such, the achievements are more jokes than anything - but the time-based ones are very possible once you realize how fun it is being -god-.(Also, the 3D options and customization are out of this world - literally..)

Posted: December 14, 2014
												Okay, for the record I did enjoy this program ( I hesitate to use the word "game" as it really isn't one). It's fun messing around with star systems and galaxies, but even that runs a bit stale after a while. The physics interactions are alright, but they all seem a bit bland, and they never actually *show* any difference on the planet, instead you're just left to assume something changed based on a few numbers going up or down. It seem they're making an improvement on this in the new version however. Honestly I'd say this simulation is a no go. It's fun, but it won't last long for gamers, and for someone who enjoys physics, you'll soon learn it's physics interactions are really rather superficial. I'd suggest getting the new version coming out sometime in the near future, as it seem to be fixing many of these issues I have with it. As this stands now however... you'd have to be one diehard astronomy enthusiast to play this for more than 2-3 hours.

Posted: December 15, 2014
												Summary: Create and destroy on a scale youve never imagined with the ultimate space simulator.Harness the power to create black holes, collide galaxies, and manipulate gravity with just a few clicks. Inspired by the software astronomers use to unlock the mysteries of our universe, never before has astronomy been so interactive or so much fun.Spawn a massive moon to tear apart Saturns rings or launch a rogue star to rip the planets from their orbits around our sun. After unleashing catastrophic destruction, create your own solar system and share it with friends.Key Features:- Interactive, real-time, n-body gravity simulator- Change any property of any object at any time- Real physics, real data, real units, real science- Compare the objects in any simulation with chart mode- Supports anaglyphic 3D glasses and 3D DLP televisions- Built in tutorials and step-by-step activities- Includes 70+ simulations both real and fantastical- Extensive editing and creation tools make it easy to build your own simulations- Latest version of Universe Sandbox 2.x with Steam Achievements

Posted: December 1, 2012
												This is, though not an original "game", quite a good one. It's a universe simulator, quite obviously, where you take a pre-existing area in space and change whatever variables you want. Watch the subtle effects on the rest of the solar system as you place another earth in orbit, or anything like that.Yet, if I had to describe this game in one word, it would be; Hilarious.Increase the Gravitational Constant to several million billion times its current value, then watch all the planets freak out and run away from each other.Best of all is the collision. One of the settings makes it so that when two objects collide, the bigger absorbs the smaller, gaining its mass.This is the only game in which I have, or could concievably dream of, encountering the following scenario.I threw Earths at my enlarged Mega-Earth to make it bigger, but I threw too many Earths that they formed their own Mega-Earth, absorbing the first one. And I was okay with it, because wut.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												If you have time to burn and like to watch galaxies collide, then this is the game simulator for you. Its fun if you are not any particular time to play a serious game or dedicate an hour or two invest. You start off with the pre-made Sol solar system that runs you through a tutorial. You can then have fun either enjoying pre-made scenarios, or have open nothingness to place a glaxay or five to watch gravity work. You have the option to speed up time, slow it down, or pause it to get a full effect of what you are doing. There is no objective, it is completely a sandbox do anything you want within the game. The only down side I have for this game, which might be in part because of my pc, I have found myself in situations where I have too many particles flying around all at once that it causes the programe to failsafe when it crashes. No big deal, I just tend to do it a lot.

Posted: July 30, 2013
												Comparing this to SpaceEngine is unfair, but I'll do it anyway. Universe Sandbox excels at:-Editing / Creating new Celestial Bodies-Creating "funny" objects and modifying the characteristics of planetoids and other bodies.-Viewing a skybox of the universe that never changes.-Crashing and lagging out 24/7.SpaceEngine excels at:-Viewing the viewable universe and local group.-A much more advanced movement palette.-Beautifully rendered nebulae and planetary atmospheres.-Native post-processing support.-It's free.-Crashing and lagging out 24/7.So basically, get Universe Sandbox if you want to crash galaxies into one another or create the star system of your favorite RPG.Forget this and get SpaceEngine if you just want to explore the universe.

												Was a pretty fun game until I discovered the 3D mode.  Absolutely epic with that feature turned on.  It's a very useful tool to visualize some of the realistic attributes of space like extreme distances and just how long it takes for cause and effect to take place.  However I find that the physics engine itself is a bit broken; if you load a simulation and just leave it to its own devices, suddenly out of nowhere a planet will go flying out of the system.  Also, it's neat to see galaxies collide and fly apart... but we know for a fact their gravity will eventually create one system instead of a mess that never reconstitutes.  Needs updating.

Posted: December 30, 2011
												Excellent sandbox for playing around with planets, galaxies, etc.  You're able to change the dynamics of the global bodies with regards to rotation, gravity, orbit, etc.  You can create your own universe, and experiment to see how your universe reacts to changes.  You can also use models already in the game (like our Solar system for instance), and change the dynamics to see what effects you'd have (Ie: increasing mars gravity so that it's twice, three times, 10 times that of the sun).  Just a fun game.I wish I had more time to play around with it.  When I do have the time to play, I'm enjoying the game for hours.  The game's worth playing... once you bought it on sale.

Posted: February 1, 2014
												Let me preface my review with this statement: Universe Sandbox is NOT a game, or at least not in any real, traditional sense. Now that I got that out of the way, I think that Universe Sandbox is indeed fun yet educational & should be in everyone's Steam library, especially if you have at least a mild interest in space, physics, and/or from time to time asked yourself miscellaneous "what if..." questions. Ever wonder what things would be like if you crushed our sun into a black hole? Ever wanted to see multiple black holes orbit each other? Want to recreate Tantooine with it's twin suns? Well, you can find out (or do) all that and more with Universe Sandbox. All in all it's just plain ol' fun to just screw around with, and seeing as there's real science & physics behind it, you just may learn something while doing so.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												Watching a simulation on how our galaxy will evolve under billions of years, collapsing into Andromeda, as galaxies drift further and further apart... That's amazing. Watching millions of years go by as fast as seconds, it gives me a brief moment of relief; A brief moment where I feel like I'm exploring eternity and not just stuck on a material-minded spec in infinity. Few games make me emotional, but the grand scope of our world and just the insane idea that through technology I can at least experience and taste but a miniscule amount of it: That made it worth the purchase ten times over for me.This isn't as much a game or a simulation as an experience really. You won't be sinking hundreds of hours into it, but those few hours you do will make you somber and tranquil if you have any depth and longing for exploration and the universe.If not, meh you can always have fun throwing starts into eachother.

Posted: September 23, 2014
												This is not really a game, more like simulation tool. Maybe this should be labelled as software instead of game.The good:+ Great visualisation of many calestial phenomenon.+ Fun way to study astronomy and astrophysics.The bad:- Use of Euler algorithm and RK4. Euler algorithm have way too large error accumulation while RK4 is too slow. I would rather use Numerov algorithm. It is very much faster.- Crash on random basis.- No idea if it is just me, there is no sound or music and it is pretty boring.This review will be updated as I use them more. I also have non-steam version and use it more often.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												Why am I writing this with less than 4 hours of play?.. Well. Simply put. It was all that was required for me to fall in love with it. Don't let the name fool you. Yes. You can toss Tea Pots at the Earth add infinadum.. but this is also a SERIOUS astronomical tool and extremely accurate simulation of Solar, Planetary and Galactic motion and distance calc.You can set parameters to create real world Physics/Astronomy experiments.. With this program you can see what the Earths night sky will look like in a Million years or a Trillion yearsSee what would happen if the Earth slowed down, sped up.. increased in mass.. Collide two Galaxies. Play Snooker with our planets. The possibilities are endless and limited only by your imagination.10/10.. I HIGHLY recommend this program to anyone who is a backyard astronomer or just likes to look at the night sky... BUT don't buy this one.. go get Ver. 2.0, out now!!

Posted: December 1, 2012
												This is, though not an original "game", quite a good one. It's a universe simulator, quite obviously, where you take a pre-existing area in space and change whatever variables you want. Watch the subtle effects on the rest of the solar system as you place another earth in orbit, or anything like that.Yet, if I had to describe this game in one word, it would be; Hilarious.Increase the Gravitational Constant to several million billion times its current value, then watch all the planets freak out and run away from each other.Best of all is the collision. One of the settings makes it so that when two objects collide, the bigger absorbs the smaller, gaining its mass.This is the only game in which I have, or could concievably dream of, encountering the following scenario.I threw Earths at my enlarged Mega-Earth to make it bigger, but I threw too many Earths that they formed their own Mega-Earth, absorbing the first one. And I was okay with it, because wut.

Posted: July 17, 2013
												Universe Sandbox is NOT a game, but rather a program to mess around with astrophysics, gravitation, and the like. It is the most accurate system of its kind, especially for its price tag. There are a couple fun things to do in the sandbox, but there isn't any value for anyone not interested in physics anyway.This program is also a nightmare for achievement hunters, requiring loopholes just to get 100% completion (there's an achievement to play it for over more than five years in time). Get it if you want to mess around for a little bit, but otherwise, skip it.
